article.title: %C3%81ed_mac_Cin%C3%A1eda
article.paragraph: RefimproveJuly 2015Infobox royaltyÁed [[List of Kings of the Picts|King of the Picts]] 877–878 [[Constantín mac Cináeda|Constantine I]] [[Giric]] [[Constantine II of Scotland|Constantine II]], King of Alba [[House of Alpin|Alpin]] [[Kenneth MacAlpin|Kenneth I]], King of the Picts before 858 878 [[Strathallan]] [[Iona]] ed mac Cineda(died 878) was a son ofCined mac Ailpn("Kenneth MacAlpin"). He became king of thePictsin 877 when he succeeded his brotherConstantn mac CinedaConstantine I. He was nicknameded of the White Flowers,the Wing-footed(lang-laalipes) orthe white-foot(lang-laalbipes).
article.heading: Sources
article.paragraph: TheChronicle of the Kings of Albasays of ed: "Edus [ed] held the same [i.e. the kingdom] for one year. The shortness of his reign has bequeathed nothing memorable to history. He was slain in the civitas of Nrurim." Nrurim is unidentified.

TheAnnals of Ulstersay that in 878: "ed mac Cineda, king of the Picts, was killed by his associates."Calise, J. M. P., ''Pictish Sourcebook'', Greenwood Publishing Group, 2002, ISBN 9780313322952Tradition, reported byGeorge Chalmers (antiquarian)George Chalmersin hisCaledonia(1807), and by theStatistical Accounts of ScotlandNew Statistical Account(1834–1845), has it that the early-historic mound of the Cunninghillock byInverurieis the burial place of ed. This is based on reading Nrurim asInruriu.

A longer account is interpolated inAndrew of Wyntoun'sOrygynale Cronykil of Scotland. This says that ed reigned one year and was killed by his successorGiricinStrathallanand other king lists have the same report.

It is uncertain which, if any, of theProphecy of Berchn's kings should be taken to be ed.William Forbes Skenepresumed that the following verses referred to ed:129. Another king will take [sovereignty]; small is the profit that he does not divide. Alas for Scotland thenceforward. His name will be the Furious.
130. He will be but a short time over Scotland. The will be no [word uncertain] unplundered. Alas for Scotland, through the youth; alas for their books, alas for their bequests.
131. He will be nine years in the kingdom. I shall tell you—it will be a tale of truth—he dies without bell, with communion, at evening, in a fatal pass.
ed's son,Constantn mac eda, became king in 900. The idea thatDomnall II of Strathclydewas a son of ed, based on a confusing entry in the Chronicle of the Kings of Alba, is contested.
